elise_plan_3.text: Can this work? Or was grandmother just as desperate as I am, grasping at any straw?

narration_plan.text: What else did she write? Three components for the seal. Hilde knows the chant. The sign of the earth — perhaps in the church? And the anchor...

choices: Go to the church — search for the sign
Seek out Hilde — ask about the chant

narration_to_church.text: The church. That's where the chamber lies, where the rituals are performed. If there are clues to the sign of the earth anywhere, it's there.

narration_to_hilde.text: Hilde was grandmother's ally. She knows the chant. Perhaps she knows more about the other components too. The church can wait.

narration_1.text: Day four. In the village square, I run into Konrad by chance — or what disguises itself as chance. He sits on the edge of the fountain, reading.

narration_inner.text: Grandmother's words stand before my eyes: 'He is the vessel.' The man who sits there so peacefully reading carries something ancient within him. And he may not even know it.

konrad_1.text: Fräulein Brandt! What a pleasant surprise. Please, sit down. I have fresh coffee — real coffee, not that substitute.

elise_greet.text: Good day, Herr Müller. My grandmother often told me about you.

konrad_react_greet.text: Did she? That pleases me. Margarethe was a special woman.

konrad_remembers_door.text: Ah, it's nice to see you in daylight. Our nighttime encounter was somewhat... unfortunate. You must think me strange.

elise_door_react.text: Yes, it surprised me. What brought you to Grandmother's house at night?

konrad_door_excuse.text: I wanted to offer my condolences. Old habit — Margarethe and I often chatted in the evenings.

narration_door.text: He is lying. Or telling a half-truth. Grandmother did not write about evening chats in her diary.

narration_suspicious.text: I know what grandmother wrote about him. The vessel. I must be careful.

narration_charmed.text: Something about him draws me in. He is different from the other villagers — educated, open, curious.

konrad_2.text: I've been thinking about your grandmother. Margarethe was a remarkable woman. Did you know she taught me to read?

elise_react_reading.text: I did not know that. She never talked much about Graubach. At least not... not in recent years.

konrad_4.text: When I was a child, she came every Wednesday. She read to me, showed me a world beyond these mountains. Without her, I would never have become a teacher.

elise_personal.text: That sounds wonderful. I wish I had visited her more often.

konrad_6.text: She always had a secret, your grandmother. Something she never shared. Have you discovered it?

narration_test_moment.text: He asks so directly. His eyes seek mine — calm, attentive. Too attentive? Or merely curious?

choices: Trust him and tell him about the tradition
Distrust: Answer evasively
Test him: Tell him about the spirals and observe his reaction

elise_trust_1.text: Herr Müller... Konrad. I know about the tradition. About the book beneath the church. About the feeding every thirty years.

konrad_trust_silence.text: He says nothing. His face barely changes — but his hands around the coffee cup turn white with tension.

konrad_trust_2.text: I know. I think I have always known. Not the details, but... the feeling. That something is wrong in this village. That I am wrong.

elise_trust_ask.text: What does it feel like? Can you... can you sense it?

konrad_trust_describe.text: Imagine you are standing in a dark room. You know you are not alone. Something breathes behind you. But when you turn around, there is only... yourself.

konrad_trust_dreams.text: Sometimes I dream things that are not my dreams. I see... deeper. Older. As though I were merely a shell.

elise_trust_vessel.text: Konrad... Grandmother called you 'the vessel' in her diary.

konrad_trust_vessel_react.text: He closes his eyes. A tremor runs through his body — brief, violent, as though an electric shock had hit him.

konrad_trust_4.text: The vessel. Yes. That... that explains a few things. You know, Fräulein Brandt, sometimes I wake at night and my hands are drawing spirals. Without my wanting them to.

narration_trust_horror.text: A shiver runs down my spine. He is describing possession from the inside — and it does not sound like a monster. It sounds like a prisoner.

elise_distrust_1.text: Nothing special. Old letters, recipes. Memories of an old woman.

narration_lie.text: The lie comes more easily than expected. But my voice sounds too high, too even.

konrad_distrust_2.text: Only memories? No... records? No notes about the village?

elise_distrust_push.text: Why would she have notes about the village?

konrad_distrust_shift.text: His smile changes. The warmth fades. For a moment something seems to slide behind his pupils. Something old.

konrad_distrust_3.text: Of course. Only memories. Graubach is a perfectly normal village, after all.

elise_distrust_shiver.text: The way he emphasizes 'normal' makes me shiver. He knows I am lying. And I know that he knows.

narration_distrust_horror.text: His voice suddenly sounds different. Deeper. Older. As though not he were speaking, but something THROUGH him. Then he blinks, and the old Konrad is back.

konrad_distrust_5.text: Forgive me. I am somewhat... out of sorts today. Sleep was not good.

elise_test_1.text: The church is fascinating. Those spirals on the walls — have you noticed them? I know similar patterns from my folklore studies.

konrad_test_react.text: His hand twitches. Involuntarily he grabs his wrist — right where I saw the faint spiral patterns on his skin at our last meeting.

konrad_test_hide.text: Spirals? I... no, I do not pay attention to church decoration. Pastor Voss's domain, not mine.

elise_test_push.text: Strange. You just covered your wrist. Do you have such patterns too?

konrad_test_3.text: Spirals? No, I... I do not know any spirals.

narration_test_lie.text: He is lying. And he knows that I know it. The air between us grows heavy. I say nothing more — sometimes silence is more revealing than questions.

konrad_walk.text: Come. Let me show you something. The forest behind the school — there is a place there that your grandmother loved.

elise_forest_hesitate.text: Alone with him in the forest. With the man grandmother called 'the vessel'. Any sensible person would refuse.

narration_forest_why.text: But I am not here to be sensible. I am here to understand.

narration_forest_1.text: The forest path leads deeper than expected. The trees stand so close together here that barely any light gets through. Konrad walks ahead, sure-footed, as though he knows every root.

konrad_forest_reply.text: Sometimes. When school is over. The forest is a good place to think.

narration_forest_walk.text: His steps are sure, almost automatic. As though his body knows the way even when his mind is elsewhere.

narration_forest_2.text: He stops at a clearing. In its center stands a single, ancient tree. Its trunk is twisted, grown in a spiral.

konrad_tree_1.text: The villagers call it the Guardian Tree. It has stood here for centuries. Your grandmother came here often.

elise_tree_1.text: Spirally grown... like the patterns in the church. Like the marks on your wrist.

konrad_tree_3.text: Do you feel it? The ground here... it breathes.

elise_tree_feel.text: Yes. Beneath my feet. A pulsing — like a heartbeat.

narration_tree.text: He's right. Beneath my feet, there is a faint pulsing. Like a heartbeat, deep in the earth. The same rhythm as beneath the altar.

konrad_humming.text: Konrad stands motionless before the tree. His lips move, barely visible. He is humming — a melody I know. The melody from the depths.

elise_humming_react.text: The song. You are humming the song — the singing from the depths!

konrad_humming_react.text: He flinches as though I had struck him. His eyes widen — confusion, fear. Real fear.

konrad_humming_2.text: I... what? I was not... I did not know I was...

narration_humming_pity.text: He does not know it. He hums the creature's song without realizing. Like a sleepwalker who does not know where his feet are taking him.

elise_humming_comfort.text: It is all right. It is not your fault, Konrad.

konrad_humming_3.text: Nothing here is my fault. And at the same time everything is my fault. Or that which is inside me.

narration_pity_moment.text: For the first time I do not see him as a threat. But as a victim. A man, trapped between himself and something older than the mountains.

journal_konrad.title: Konrad and the Guardian Tree
journal_konrad.content: Konrad showed me the Guardian Tree in the forest — grown in a spiral. The ground there pulses like beneath the altar. Konrad behaved strangely — his hand twitches at the mention of spirals, his eyes change. Grandmother's journal confirmed it: He is the vessel.

narration_return.text: We walk back to the village in silence. Konrad whistles softly to himself. The melody sounds familiar — it is the singing from the depths.

elise_return_thought.text: Can one free a vessel without breaking it? Or has Konrad Müller long since ceased to be Konrad Müller?

narration_2.text: His smile is warm, inviting. But grandmother's words echo: 'His eyes were not his own.'

konrad_door_narration.text: He mentions our encounter casually, as if it were the most normal thing in the world. But why was he at grandmother's house at night?

konrad_trusted.text: I tell him everything. About the tradition, the book, the feeding. He listens without interrupting.

konrad_trusted_3.text: I know. I think I've always known. Not the details, but... the feeling. That something is wrong in this village. That something is wrong with me.

konrad_trusted_5.text: Sometimes I dream things that are not my dreams. I see... deeper. Older. As though I were merely a shell.

konrad_trusted_6.text: He says it so calmly, so matter-of-factly. As though he were talking about the weather.

konrad_distrusted.text: 'Nothing special,' I say. 'Old letters, recipes, memories.' The lie tastes bitter.

konrad_distrusted_3.text: He smiles, but the smile doesn't reach his eyes. For a moment — just a moment — something seems to slide behind his pupils. Something ancient.

konrad_distrusted_4.text: Of course. Only memories. After all, Graubach is a perfectly normal village.

konrad_tested.text: I mention the spirals in the church in passing. 'Strange patterns,' I say. 'Do you know them?'

konrad_tested_2.text: His hand twitches. Involuntarily, he grasps his wrist — right where I noticed the faint spiral patterns on his skin the other day.

konrad_tested_4.text: Spirals? No, I... I don't know any spirals.

konrad_tested_5.text: He's lying. And he knows that I know it. The air between us grows heavy.

narration_1.text: Day five. Midnight. The village sleeps — or pretends to. I creep through the empty lanes toward the church.

narration_2.text: Georg's key sits heavy in my pocket. Hilde's amulet rests against my chest. Grandmother's journal is in my bag.

elise_inner_ready.text: My hands tremble. But I keep walking. Grandmother worked towards this moment for thirty years. I will not let it pass.

voss_night_1.text: You came. Good. We have little time. Otto's men are patrolling — he has noticed that something is changing in the village.

elise_voss_greet.text: Thank you for being here, Father. I would not have wanted to do this alone.

voss_night_2.text: Voss leads me through a side door into the sacristy. There, behind a heavy curtain, lies a stone staircase leading downward.

narration_voss_leads.text: Voss leads me through a side door into the sacristy. There, behind a heavy curtain, lies a stone staircase leading downward.

narration_alone.text: The church door is locked. But Georg's key — it fits here too. The old iron turns heavily in the lock.

elise_alone_thought.text: Alone. No Voss, no Georg. Just me and whatever waits beneath the church. Grandmother did it alone for thirty years. I can manage one night.

narration_alone_2.text: Alone in the dark church. My candle casts trembling shadows. Behind the altar I find the staircase leading down.

narration_basement_1.text: The air changes at once. Warmer, damper, sweeter. The singing is no longer faint here — it fills the room, vibrates in my bones.

elise_descent_react.text: Nausea rises in me. Dizziness. The amulet on my chest grows warm - as though it were working against the pressure weighing on my thoughts.

narration_basement_2.text: The walls are covered with spirals. Carved, painted, branded. Layer upon layer, centuries piled atop one another. Some look like writing I cannot read.

voss_descent_1.text: Herr im Himmel, steh uns bei...

voss_descent_2.text: Nicht gegen DAS hier. Aber es hilft mir. Es erinnert mich daran, wer ich bin.

elise_voss_understand.text: I understand him. Down here, where the walls breathe and the ground pulses, one needs something to anchor oneself. For Voss it is his faith. For me... Grandmother's words.

narration_basement_3.text: On a stone pedestal in the center of the room lies a book. It is not old — it is beyond old. The leather is from no animal I know.

elise_book_first.text: My hands tremble as I touch it. The leather feels like... skin. Warm skin. It responds to my touch - a gentle pulsing beneath my fingertips.

narration_basement_4.text: I open it. Page after page of names. Hundreds of names, in different handwritings, written across centuries. Some have a date behind them. Some have a cross.

elise_crosses.text: The crosses. One every thirty years. The sacrificed. I count them and my stomach turns. So many. So many people who descended into this hole and never came back up.

narration_basement_5.text: The crosses. I count them. One every thirty years, going back until... the oldest entries are no longer writing, just symbols.

elise_grandmother_notes.text: Her notes. Small, neat letters: 'Friedrich Meier, 1893. Last sacrifice.' And further on: 'Konrad M. - not entered as sacrifice. Marked differently. Vessel?' Grandmother studied this book. For years.

narration_find_name.text: And there, on the last written page: 'Elise Brandt'. In a handwriting that does not look human. The letters are too even, too perfect.

elise_panic_1.text: My name. In a script no human can write. And the ink... the ink PULSES. It lives. It breathes beneath my fingers.

elise_panic_2.text: No. No, that cannot be. It must be a mistake. Someone wrote it in - Otto, Konrad, someone. But the script is not human. No human hand writes like this.

narration_name_1.text: I touch my name on the page. The ink is warm. It pulses beneath my fingers.

elise_panic_3.text: Grandmother knew. She summoned me BECAUSE my name stands in the book. Did she sacrifice me or save me? Or both?

narration_name_2.text: And then the singing stops. Complete, absolute silence. Silence that weighs heavier than any sound.

narration_silence.text: In the silence I feel it. Not hear, not see — feel. An attention, vast as an ocean, directed at me. It is awake. It knows I am here.

elise_awareness.text: It regards me. Not with eyes - with something older. I stand naked before a consciousness that saw mountains when they were not yet mountains.

narration_before_choice.text: The book lies open before me. My name stares back at me. What do I do now?

elise_deliberate_1.text: If I erase the name - will I be free? Or will it only anger the creature? Grandmother wrote that the name always comes back.

elise_deliberate_2.text: If I take the book, I have proof. Control. But Otto will notice. And the creature... it will know something is missing.

elise_deliberate_3.text: Or I leave it here. Perhaps I do not need the book. Perhaps I need the CONNECTION that my name represents.

choices: Try to scratch out the name
Take the book
Back away — leave the book alone

erase_attempt.text: I scrape my fingernail across my name. The ink does not yield. I spit on the page, rub — nothing. As grandmother wrote: the name always comes back.

elise_erase_frustrate.text: As Grandmother wrote: the name always comes back. As though it were not ON the page, but IN it. Part of the book itself.

erase_3.text: The ground trembles. Dust trickles from the ceiling. The singing resumes — louder, angrier, like a swarm of hornets rising from the deep.

take_book.text: I close the book and take it. It is heavier than it looks, and warm, almost hot. As I lift it from the pedestal, the room shudders.

take_3.text: A sound — not singing, not a scream. A sigh. So vast, so deep that the stone walls vibrate. It has noticed that something is missing.

elise_take_react.text: The book presses against my chest like a heartbeat that is not my own. But I hold it tight. It belongs to me - or I belong to it.

leave_book.text: I step back. My instinct tells me: the book is not meant for human hands. It belongs below, in the dark, where it was placed.

elise_leave_reason.text: I do not need the book. I have something better: I now know that my name is a connection. And a connection can be used - without possessing it.

leave_2.text: The singing resumes gently. Almost satisfied. As if I had made the right decision — or the one it wanted.

book_converge.text: I must get out of here. Now. The walls seem to be closing in, the spirals spinning in my peripheral vision.

narration_escape.text: I stumble up the stairs, through the church, into the open air. The night air hits me like a blow. Cold. Clear. Real.

otto_encounter.text: In front of the church stands a figure in the moonlight. Broad-shouldered, motionless. Mayor Reinhardt.

otto_1.text: Fräulein Brandt. Out late. And with something that does not belong to you.

elise_otto_react.text: Herr Reinhardt. How long have you been standing here?

otto_2.text: Lange genug. Ich habe Sie beobachtet, seit Sie Hildes Hütte verlassen haben. Genau wie Ihre Großmutter - immer da, wo sie nicht sein sollte.

otto_3.text: Give me the book. And go home. Forget what you have seen. That is not a request.

elise_otto_defiant.text: My name stands in this book, Herr Reinhardt. In a script no human wrote. I believe I have a right to it.

otto_react_name.text: Rights? There are no rights here, Fräulein. There is only tradition. And tradition says: every thirty years it is fed. That has worked. For centuries.

choices: Give back the book
Refuse and run

give_book.text: My hands tremble as I hand him the book. Otto takes it with a care that contradicts his threat. He holds it like a baby.

give_book_3.text: Sensible. Just like your grandmother. She was sensible too — in the end. Go home, Fräulein Brandt. And stay there.

elise_give_whisper.text: In the end. What does that mean? Was Grandmother sensible - or did Otto silence her? The thought makes me shiver.

defy_otto.text: I press the book against my chest and run. Through the lanes, across the square, toward grandmother's house. Otto calls after me, but he does not pursue.

defy_narration.text: I press the book against my chest and run. Through the alleys, across the square, towards Grandmother's house. Otto calls after me, but he does not give chase.

defy_3.text: His last words echo through the night: 'That was a mistake, Fräulein Brandt. A grave mistake.'

defy_4.text: His call echoes through the night. But I am faster than an old man. And the darkness shields me - for the first time.

narration_home_1.text: Back in grandmother's house. I bolt the door, shove a chair against it. My hands are still trembling.

elise_home_process.text: I saw my name. In a script no human wrote. On a page that knows no error. And now I know for certain: I am no bystander. I am part of the story.

journal_book.title: The Book of Names
journal_book.content: In the chamber beneath the church lies an ancient book containing hundreds of names. Some bear a cross — the sacrificed, every 30 years. My name is the last entry, in inhuman script. The ink pulses. The entity knew I would come.

narration_end_1.text: I cannot sleep. The singing is louder than ever. It seeps through the walls, through the floor, through my closed eyelids.

elise_end_cover.text: I press my hands over my ears. It does not help. The singing does not come from outside. It comes from WITHIN. Since I touched my name, it is part of me.

narration_end_2.text: And in the pauses between the tones I hear words. Not German, not Latin, no language that should exist. But I understand them all the same.

narration_end_3.text: It says my name. Over and over and over. Elise. Elise. Elise.

narration_home_2.text: I have seen my name. In a script no human wrote. On a page that knows no error.

narration_1.text: Day six, afternoon. Tomorrow is the anniversary. I need help - and I must decide whom I trust.

elise_assess.text: Georg has the key and the strength. Hilde knows the chant and the old ways. Voss knows the chamber and carries thirty years of guilt. And Konrad... Konrad is the key to everything - or the greatest danger.

elise_decide.text: I cannot confide in all of them at once. Otto has eyes everywhere. One must be my primary ally - the one I rely on tomorrow night.

choices: Choose Georg as main ally - strength and loyalty
Choose Hilde as main ally - knowledge and experience
Choose Voss as main ally - access and remorse

georg_ally_1.text: You really want to go through with it. Margarethe's ritual. I hoped you'd leave, Elise. But I also knew you'd stay.

elise_georg_1.text: Leaving was never really an option. Not since I saw my name in that book.

georg_flee_callback.text: You wanted to flee, back then. That was sensible. But you stayed. That was brave. Your grandmother would be proud.

elise_georg_flee.text: The forest would not let me. But even if it had... I believe I would have come back.

elise_georg_question.text: Georg, what happens if I fail? What happens to you, to Graubach?

georg_ally_answer.text: Then it was all for nothing. Thirty years. Margarethe's sacrifice. My guilt.

elise_georg_risk.text: And you? What are you risking? You could flee - you are not in the book.

georg_ally_3.text: I'm in. I'll stop Otto when he comes. He will come - he has men, but I have hammers. And thirty years of pent-up rage.

elise_georg_otto.text: Otto has men. What if they are armed?

georg_ally_hammer.text: Georg takes a heavy blacksmith's hammer from the wall. In his eyes burns a fire I have never seen before.

georg_ally_4.text: Georg takes a heavy blacksmith's hammer from the wall. In his eyes burns a fire I've never seen before. Perhaps the fire that has only smoldered for thirty years.

elise_georg_grateful.text: Thank you, Georg. Grandmother could not have wished for a better ally.

hilde_ally_1.text: Tomorrow, then. The chant must begin at sunset, when the entity lies between sleep and waking. That's when it's most vulnerable.

elise_hilde_1.text: Hilde, the chant... I cannot do it alone. When I tried it at your cottage, my voice was barely enough.

hilde_ally_2.text: I'll help you strengthen the chant. My voice may be old, but together - perhaps it will suffice. The ancient peoples always sang in chorus.

elise_hilde_chance.text: What if the creature does not accept the chant? What if it is not enough?

hilde_ally_improvise.text: Then we improvise. As your grandmother would have done. Margarethe never gave up - and neither shall we.

hilde_ally_personal.text: Hilde takes my hands. Her fingers are rough and warm, full of life despite her age.

hilde_ally_hands.text: You are more like her than you think, child. The same stubbornness. The same kindness. And the same fear she never admitted to.

elise_hilde_personal.text: Hatte sie Angst? Großmutter wirkte immer so... unerschütterlich.

hilde_ally_truth.text: Of course she was afraid. Every night. But she used the fear - as fuel. You can do the same.

hilde_ally_3.text: Hilde begins tying bundles of herbs together and painting signs on strips of cloth. She murmurs the chant softly as she works. The air in the cottage thickens.

voss_ally_1.text: Thirty years I have kept silent. Thirty years I have stood by and watched. That ends tomorrow.

elise_voss_1.text: Pastor Voss, you have suffered under guilt for thirty years. That is enough.

voss_reacts.text: Nothing is ever enough. Not for Friedrich Meier. Not for all the others.

elise_voss_lead.text: Then help me end it. Not for the guilt - for the future. So that no one is ever sacrificed again.

voss_confronted_callback.text: You asked me in the church what I knew about the Feeding. I didn't say everything then. But now - I owe you the full truth. And I owe Friedrich Meier more than that.

voss_confession.text: Friedrich screamed. All night. And I... I prayed instead of helping him. I spoke my prayers louder than his screams. I will never forgive myself for that.

elise_voss_forgive.text: You cannot undo it. But you can make sure it was the last time.

voss_ally_3.text: I know every stone in that chamber. I know where the traps are, where the ground is thin, where the singing grows loudest. I will guide you.

elise_voss_risk.text: What if Otto stops us? He controls the village.

voss_ally_4.text: And if it goes wrong... then I go first. I owe that to Friedrich Meier. I owe that to everyone.

elise_voss_no.text: No one has to die, Pastor. Not you, not I. That is what we are doing this for.

ally_converge.text: I have an ally. But is it enough? Evening falls, and with it the world grows stranger still.

elise_konrad_consider.text: But then there is Konrad. The vessel. The man caught between himself and the creature. Can he help me - or will he betray me?

choices: Seek out Konrad - perhaps he can resist the entity
Avoid Konrad - he is too dangerous

konrad_final_1.text: Konrad sits alone in the classroom. He has drawn spirals on the blackboard - dozens, intertwined. When I enter, he hastily wipes them away.

konrad_final_2.text: Elise. I... it's getting worse. I'm losing myself. At night I wake up in places I never went to. My hands do things I don't want.

elise_konrad_concern.text: When did you last sleep? Truly sleep?

konrad_final_sleep.text: I do not know anymore. The nights blur together. Sometimes I do not know if I am awake or dreaming. Whether it is ME thinking or IT.

konrad_final_4.text: His eyes flicker - brown, then something else, deeper, older. For a moment I see something immense behind his pupils, like an ocean behind a pane of glass.

konrad_creature_voice.text: Elise... it is HERE... it speaks through me... I cannot...

elise_konrad_reach.text: Konrad! Listen to my voice. YOU are Konrad Müller. You are a teacher. You learned to read from Grandmother.

konrad_final_6.text: Help me, Elise. Please. Before it has me completely. I don't want to be its tool.

elise_konrad_promise.text: I will free you, Konrad. Or at least try. I promise.

konrad_final_hope.text: A faint smile. The first genuine smile I have seen from him - not charming, not seductive. Only grateful. Only human.

avoided_konrad.text: Konrad is no longer Konrad. Not entirely. I can't risk the entity learning of my plan through him.

elise_konrad_regret.text: I am sorry, Konrad. Perhaps I can help you when this is over. But now... now I must avoid you. For your own protection.

ally_final_converge.text: Der Abend bricht herein. Der Himmel färbt sich in Farben, die es nicht geben sollte - violett und grün und ein Rot, das an Wunden erinnert.
ally_final_converge.title: Allies Chosen
ally_final_converge.content: Tomorrow is the day of the Feeding. I have chosen my allies and discussed the plan. Grandmother's binding ritual instead of the blood ritual. Anna says the entity is afraid of me. That makes two of us.

elise_final_thought.text: Tomorrow is the day. Tomorrow I stand in the chamber, above the thinnest stone, and sing the chant Hilde taught me. And the creature will answer.

journal_allies.title: Allies Chosen
journal_allies.content: Tomorrow is the day of the feeding. I have chosen my allies and discussed the plan. Grandmother's binding ritual instead of the blood ritual. Anna says the creature is afraid of me. That makes two of us.

narration_2.text: Georg has the key and the strength. Hilde knows the chant and the old ways. Voss knows the chamber. And Konrad... Konrad is the key to everything - or the greatest danger.

narration_1.text: Day seven. Evening. The church no longer looks like a church. The pews are shifted, some hovering centimeters above the floor. The stained-glass windows show images that do not belong in glass.

narration_2.text: The singing is everywhere. No longer just from the depths — it comes from the walls, from the air, from inside my own head. Hilde's amulet pulses warm against my chest.

narration_3.text: I stand before the stairs to the chamber. The key in my hand is warm — not from my body heat. A warmth of its own.

narration_resolve.text: My heart pounds. But my hands are steady. Grandmother's hands, Georg said. Hands that do not tremble when it matters.

elise_ally_georg_1.text: No. But when would one be ready for something like this?

georg_ally_2.text: Margarethe said the same thing, back then. Word for word.

elise_ally_georg_2.text: Then at least she left me that.

narration_ally_together.text: He nods. No more words needed. We go together.

hilde_ally_1.text: The church is resisting. Can you feel it? The stones are bristling.

elise_ally_hilde_1.text: Mostly I feel the singing. It is... louder than last night. Closer.

hilde_ally_2.text: That is good. It knows you are coming. It expects you.

elise_ally_hilde_2.text: That is supposed to reassure me?

hilde_ally_3.text: It is supposed to prepare you. I leave the reassurance to the valerian.

narration_hilde_smile.text: Despite everything, I have to smile. Hilde has that way of taking the edge off the terror.

voss_ally_1.text: God help us. The church... my church... what has it done to her?

elise_ally_voss_1.text: It is showing us what has always been beneath the surface, Pastor. Are you ready?

voss_ally_2.text: For thirty years I have dreaded this night. But now... now I am almost relieved that it is finally here.

elise_ally_voss_2.text: Relief before the abyss. I understand what you mean.

narration_voss_together.text: Voss crosses himself. His hands tremble, but his steps are firm. Thirty years of guilt are a heavy anchor.

narration_alone.text: I am alone. No ally, no protector. Only me, the key, and the singing.

narration_alone_2.text: Grandmother did it alone for thirty years. Perhaps that runs in the family.

otto_confrontation.text: The church door flies open. Otto Reinhardt stands in the entrance, flanked by two men with torches. His expression is cold.

otto_conf_1.text: I warned you, Fräulein Brandt. The tradition is older than you, older than I, older than this village. And you will not break it.

elise_otto_1.text: Tradition? You mean: murder. Every thirty years a murder, so you get to play mayor.

otto_conf_2.text: So that this village EXISTS! Do you think anyone LIKES living next to such an entity? We do what is necessary!

elise_otto_2.text: My grandmother searched for another way for thirty years. I will find it.

otto_conf_3.text: Your grandmother DIED before she found one!

narration_otto_silence.text: The words hit. For a moment I cannot breathe. He is right. Grandmother searched for thirty years and died without finding a solution.

elise_otto_3.text: Then at least she showed me the way. Step aside, Otto.

georg_defends_1.text: Enough, Otto. For thirty years I watched. For thirty years I stayed silent. That is over.

georg_defends_2.text: Georg steps between me and Otto. In his hand the blacksmith's hammer. Otto backs away — he knows Georg, knows his strength.

georg_defends_3.text: Go, Elise. I will hold them off. Do what Margarethe planned.

georg_defends_4.text: I am a blacksmith. We are tough.

ally_confronts_otto.text: Otto Reinhardt. I knew your father and your grandfather. They all had more courage than you. Let us through.

narration_hilde_otto.text: Hilde steps forward, small and old and utterly unyielding. Otto hesitates. In Graubach, no one contradicts Hilde.

voss_confronts_otto.text: Otto, I have been silent for thirty years about what happened in 1893. Do you really want me to start talking now?

narration_voss_threat.text: Otto's face loses all color. Whatever Voss knows — it is enough to bring down a mayor.

otto_retreats.text: You are bringing death upon this village. Upon all of us.

elise_otto_retreat.text: No. I am bringing the end of the killing.

otto_blocks.text: Step back. Immediately. Or you will share the fate of all who have stood against the tradition.

elise_otto_alone.text: If the entity wants me, Otto — do you really believe you can prevent it?

narration_dodge.text: But the church is on my side — or the entity beneath it. The flagstones under Otto's feet tremble, and he stumbles. I seize the moment and run for the stairs.

narration_dodge_2.text: I run for the stairs, past the stumbling men. Otto's shouts fade behind me, swallowed by the singing.

otto_surprise.text: No one stopped me. Perhaps Otto knows nothing. Perhaps he is busy elsewhere. Or perhaps something is letting me through on purpose.

narration_otto_surprise_2.text: Or perhaps something is letting me through on purpose. The thought is worse than any confrontation.

narration_descent_1.text: The staircase spirals downward. Of course. Everything here is spiral. Each step brings me closer to the singing. It does not grow louder — it grows truer.

narration_descent_2.text: The air is thick and sweet. My candlelight flickers, though no draft blows. The spirals on the walls seem to move when I am not looking directly at them.

descent_georg_dialogue.text: Georg... the walls. The spirals are moving.

georg_descent_1.text: Don't look. Just keep walking. Margarethe said that too.

elise_descent_georg.text: How often was she down here?

georg_descent_2.text: Too often. Each time she came back... changed. Quieter. As if each descent took a piece of her.

narration_descent_cost.text: What did it take from her? What will it take from me? The questions hammer in my head, in time with the singing.

descent_hilde_dialogue.text: Breathe evenly. The air down here wants to confuse you. It lies.

elise_descent_hilde.text: The sweetness... is that the breath of the entity?

hilde_descent_1.text: In a way. It dreams, and its breath is the scent of its dreams. Not pleasant dreams.

elise_descent_hilde_2.text: What does something older than the trees dream of?

hilde_descent_2.text: Of company. That is the sad part.

descent_voss_dialogue.text: Our Father, who art in heaven...

elise_descent_voss.text: Does the praying help down here?

voss_descent_1.text: Not against THIS. But it helps ME. And that must be enough.

elise_descent_voss_2.text: You were here. In 1893. When Friedrich died. How... how was it back then?

voss_descent_2.text: Exactly like this. The same sweetness, the same singing. Only... back then we did not try to stop it. We FED it.

narration_descent_alone.text: Alone in the depths. My steps echo, but the echo returns wrong — too late, too loud, as if someone were following me.

narration_descent_alone_2.text: I turn around. Nothing. Only darkness and spirals. But I FEEL something. Attention. It has been watching me since I touched its name.

narration_descent_3.text: Then: the chamber. Larger than expected. The stone here is not masoned — it has grown. Organic, like the inside of a vast creature.

narration_descent_4.text: Deeper. Still deeper. The steps stop being even. Some are wider than others, some tilted, as if the earth had shifted beneath them.

narration_descent_5.text: A tremor runs through the stone. Not from outside. From BELOW. As if something vast had turned in its sleep.

narration_descent_6.text: Then: the chamber. Larger than expected. The stone here is not masoned — it has grown. Organic, like the inside of a vast creature.

narration_chamber_1.text: In the center of the chamber lies the book. Beside it: a circle of ancient symbols, carved into the stone. And in the middle of the circle: a spot where the floor pulses.

narration_chamber_2.text: The sign of the earth. Here it is. I feel the heartbeat through the soles of my shoes, stronger than ever before. It lives. It waits.

narration_chamber_3.text: My breath comes heavy. The air down here tastes of something primordial — of moss and stone and something alive that knows no daylight.

narration_chamber_elise_1.text: Between me and IT there is only stone. Thin stone. I place my hand on the pulsing floor, and for a moment — I feel it.

narration_chamber_contact.text: An ocean. Not water, but consciousness. Old and vast and slow. It notices my hand the way a sleeping giant notices a fly on its nose.

narration_chamber_withdraw.text: I pull my hand back. My heart pounds. Not from fear — from awe. Whatever lies beneath, it is VAST. Larger than Graubach, larger than anything I can imagine.

georg_chamber_react.text: Elise? You've gone pale. What did you feel?

elise_chamber_react.text: It is... it is so much larger than I thought. Georg, how did Grandmother endure this for thirty years?

georg_chamber_2.text: Because she was stronger than anyone knew. And you are her granddaughter.

hilde_chamber_react.text: You touched it. I can see it in your eyes.

elise_chamber_hilde.text: It is an ocean, Hilde. An ocean of consciousness. How can something be so... VAST?

hilde_chamber_2.text: It was here before the mountains. Before the rivers. It is the reason the soil here is fertile. Everything has its price.

voss_chamber_react.text: You can feel it, can't you? This... pressure. As if standing before something sacred. Or unholy.

elise_chamber_voss.text: Perhaps both. Perhaps the difference is not as great as we think.

voss_chamber_2.text: That... is a heretical thought. But down here it sounds true.

narration_chamber_alone.text: I am alone with it. With IT. The entity beneath the stone. And for the first time, that feels right. This meeting was always meant for just the two of us.

journal_descent.title: The Descent
journal_descent.content: I am in the chamber beneath the church. The floor pulses, the walls live, the singing fills everything. The Book of Names lies here. The sign of the earth — the pulsing point — is in the center. Tomorrow I perform the ritual. Or die trying.

narration_end_1.text: I stand in the chamber, and the entity knows I am here. Between us lies only thin stone and centuries of waiting.

narration_end_1b.text: And tomorrow... tomorrow the stone falls.

narration_end_2.text: Tomorrow it ends. One way or another.

narration_1.text: The last night before the ritual. I sit at my grandmother's table, her journal open, her candle burning. How often did she sit here?

narration_2.text: Outside, the sky is wrong. Stars that should not exist, in patterns reminiscent of spirals. The moon is too large and too close.

narration_3.text: I read my grandmother's final entries once more. The last pages, written in the days before her death.

narration_hands.text: My hands lie on the table. Grandmother's hands, Georg said. I study them. Slender fingers, no calluses. What are these hands supposed to do tomorrow?

narration_journal_open.text: I read Grandmother's final entries once more. The last pages, written in the days before her death. The handwriting grows unsteady toward the end, trembling.

narration_journal_1.text: 'I am too old. My body is failing. But Elise will come. The entity shows it to me in its dreams — not as a threat, as a prophecy.'

narration_react_1.text: It dreamed of me. This primordial thing dreamed of ME. The thought makes me shiver.

narration_journal_2.text: 'She has my blood. She has my will. And she has something I never had: the ability to accept the unknown without fearing it.'

narration_react_2.text: Without fearing it? Grandmother, if you could see me now. My hands are trembling, and the singing in my head grows louder every hour.

narration_journal_4.text: 'The ritual has six paths. Six possible endings. Not all are good. But all are better than the Feeding.'

narration_react_3.text: Six paths. Six possibilities. I count them on my fingers: seal, understand, destroy, negotiate, sacrifice, flee. Each has its price.

narration_journal_5.text: 'Elise, if you are reading this: trust your instinct. The entity is not evil. It is only old and hungry and alone. Sometimes that is worse than malice.'

narration_react_4.text: Old and hungry and alone. Like someone sitting in a dark room waiting for visitors who never come. For six hundred years.

narration_letter.text: Between the last pages lies an envelope. 'For Elise' is written on it, in Grandmother's best handwriting. My name in ink, not in blood.

narration_letter_read.text: 'My dearest Elise. If you are reading this, I am no longer here. But I am with you. In the herbs Hilde gives you. In the strength Georg shows you. In this house that protects you.'

narration_letter_2.text: 'I summoned you because you are the only one who can end it. Not because your name is in the book. But because you are MY granddaughter. And my granddaughter does not give up.'

narration_letter_cry.text: The ink blurs. No — that is me. I am crying. For the first time since arriving in Graubach, I cry properly. Not quietly. Not bravely. I weep like a child who has lost her grandmother.

narration_letter_3.text: 'Forgive me for summoning you. Forgive me for not being strong enough to end it alone. And forgive the entity, if you can. It does not know what it does. It only knows that it is hungry.'

narration_after_letter.text: I fold the letter and tuck it into my breast pocket. Next to Hilde's amulet. Close to the heart.

narration_georg_knock.text: A knock at the door. I wipe my eyes before opening. Georg stands outside, a lantern in his hand.

georg_visit_1.text: Couldn't sleep either. May I come in?

elise_georg_visit_1.text: Please. I... just read Grandmother's last letter.

georg_visit_2.text: She told me she would leave you one. She spent months writing it.

elise_georg_visit_2.text: Georg... what really happens tomorrow? Not the short version. The truth.

georg_visit_3.text: You descend into the chamber. You step before the entity. And then... then it is up to you. To what you choose.

georg_visit_4.text: Your grandmother believed so. For thirty years. That must be enough.

narration_georg_silence.text: Silence. Georg looks at me, and in his eyes lies something he will never say aloud. He is afraid. Not for himself. For me.

georg_visit_5.text: Then I will be with you. Whatever happens.

narration_georg_leave.text: He squeezes my shoulder, stands up, leaves. At the door he turns once more, says nothing, only nods. Then he is gone.

narration_hilde_knock.text: A knock. Soft, firm. I open. Hilde stands at the door, a pouch of herbs in her hand. She sees my eyes and nods knowingly.

hilde_visit_1.text: You have been crying. Good. Those who weep before the battle have no tears left afterward.

elise_hilde_visit_1.text: Grandmother's letter. She... she apologized. For summoning me.

hilde_visit_2.text: She apologized for thirty years. To me, to Georg, to the stars. But you were always the only one it counted for.

elise_hilde_visit_2.text: Hilde... was she afraid? At the end?

hilde_visit_3.text: No. At the end she was calm. She said: 'Elise will come. She will find the right way.' Then she smiled and closed her eyes.

elise_hilde_visit_3.text: Where does that certainty come from? I am not certain. Not even close.

hilde_visit_4.text: Your grandmother took Elise's hands. You are more like her than you think. And the entity knows it.

narration_hilde_leave.text: Hilde places the herbs on the table, strokes my hair the way Grandmother used to, and quietly leaves.

narration_voss_knock.text: A knock. Hesitant, almost shy. Voss stands at the door, his collar turned up against the night. He looks as if he has not slept in days.

voss_visit_1.text: Fräulein Brandt... Elise. I wanted... I must tell you something. Before tomorrow...

elise_voss_visit_1.text: Come in, Pastor. It is cold outside.

voss_visit_2.text: 1893... when Friedrich died... I was not merely present. I prayed. Not against the ritual. FOR the ritual. I begged God that it would work. That the sacrifice would be accepted.

elise_voss_visit_2.text: You were young. And frightened. Anyone would have —

voss_visit_3.text: No. Not anyone. Not your grandmother. She was the only one who screamed. The only one who tried to stop it. And I... I kept praying.

elise_voss_visit_3.text: Then pray for the right thing tomorrow. That is enough, Pastor.

voss_visit_4.text: Tomorrow I pray for YOU. That is more than I did for Friedrich.

narration_voss_leave.text: Voss stands, bows deeply — deeper than a pastor should bow before a parishioner — and walks out into the night.

narration_alone_night.text: No one knocks. I am alone. As Grandmother was for thirty years. Alone with the singing and the shadows and the question whether tomorrow will be the last day of my life.

narration_alone_night_2.text: I write a letter. In case I do not come back. To no one in particular. To the world that knows nothing of Graubach.

narration_approach.text: The night grows older. The singing quieter, as if the entity were holding its breath. It is waiting for my decision.

narration_approach_think.text: I close the journal. My hands are calm. Strangely calm for someone who will face an ancient entity tomorrow.

narration_approach_seal.text: Seal: Grandmother's way. Bind it, not kill it. Safe. Proven. But it lasts only thirty years. Then someone else must live through this night.

narration_approach_understand.text: Understand: What does it want? Why is it here? For six hundred years we sacrifice to it without ever asking. Perhaps the answer is the solution.

narration_approach_destroy.text: Destroy: Final. Forever. No seal that needs renewing. No more sacrifice. But the price... Grandmother wrote that destruction costs the destroyer.

narration_approach_pact.text: Negotiate: A pact. Give and take. Less than sacrifice, more than ignorance. But: can you trust an entity that has accepted six hundred years of human sacrifice?

choices: Renew the seal — Grandmother's way. Bind it, not kill it.
Try to understand it — communicate instead of fight
Destroy it — whatever the cost
Strike a pact — negotiate instead of violence

approach_seal.text: Grandmother's way. Renew the seal, sing the entity back into deep sleep. Not forever — but for another thirty years. Enough time for the next generation.

approach_seal_2.text: Grandmother showed the way. I just need to follow her footsteps. The chant, the earth sign, the anchor. Three components, one ritual. I can do this.

approach_understand.text: What is it? Why is it here? For six hundred years we sacrifice to it, without ever asking what it wants. Perhaps there is a way no one has seen.

approach_understand_2.text: I am a folklorist. I study the unknown. If anyone is capable of communicating with something no human understands, it should be me.

approach_destroy.text: Enough. No compromises, no negotiations, no seal that needs renewing in thirty years. It ends here. Today. Forever.

approach_destroy_2.text: Grandmother wrote that destruction costs the destroyer. I am willing to pay that price. Six hundred years of blood are enough.

approach_pact.text: Negotiate. It is intelligent enough to understand a pact. Perhaps there is something it wants that does not cost a human sacrifice. A bargain.

approach_pact_2.text: My name is in the book. That gives me a connection, a voice. For the first time in six hundred years, someone will TALK to the entity, not sacrifice to it.

narration_preparation.text: I lay out the things I need: Georg's key. Hilde's amulet and herbs. Grandmother's journal. My grandmother's candle.

narration_preparation_2.text: And the letter. Grandmother's letter. Not because it is a tool. But because I want to have it with me when the time comes.

narration_ready.text: Hilde's amulet warms my hand. The stone pulses in the same rhythm as the floor in the chamber. Two hearts beating in time.

narration_unprepared.text: I am missing things. But time is running out. I will have to work with what I have. Courage and desperation will have to suffice.

narration_write_letter.text: I pick up a pen. In case I do not return, someone should know what happened here. What I tried.

narration_write_letter_2.text: 'Whoever reads this: beneath the church of Graubach sleeps something old. It is not evil. It is hungry. And the people living above it have chosen the wrong way to feed it for six hundred years.'

narration_write_letter_3.text: 'My name is Elise Brandt, and tonight I am trying to find a better way. If I fail, please — do not come to Graubach. Not in thirty years. Not in a hundred. Leave it in peace.'

narration_write_letter_end.text: I put the pen down. There is nothing more to write. Nothing more to do. Only wait.

narration_dawn_2.text: Dawn breaks. It is red. Blood-red. Not the sunrise — the sky itself seems to bleed.

narration_dawn_3.text: I stand up. Stretch my back. Breathe in, breathe out. The last ordinary act of my old life.

narration_dawn_4.text: Today the story of Graubach ends. Six hundred years of tradition, six hundred years of fear, six hundred years of blood. Today I decide how.

narration_dawn_5.text: I take Grandmother's key, pocket the letter, extinguish the candle. It does not go out. Of course not.

narration_dawn_final.text: I leave it burning. Perhaps it will light my way back. If there is a way back.

journal_preparation.title: The Last Night
journal_preparation.content: Read Grandmother's final journal entries. The ritual has six possible endings. She wrote: 'The entity is not evil. It is only old and hungry and alone.' Tomorrow at sunset it begins. I am as ready as I will ever be.

narration_1.text: Day six. Something is different. When I look out the window, the colors are wrong. The sky is too violet for morning. The shadows fall in the wrong direction.

elise_mirror.text: In the mirror I see myself. But my reflection blinks half a second later than I do.

elise_mirror_react.text: I step back. My heart pounds. The reflection smiles - half a second after I stopped smiling. I turn the mirror to the wall.

narration_3.text: I turn away. This is what grandmother described: 'The dreams seep upward.' Reality is growing thin.

elise_morning_plan.text: Übermorgen ist der dreißigste Jahrestag. Ich habe einen Tag. EINEN Tag, um alles vorzubereiten. Verbündete finden, den Gesang üben, mich der Kammer stellen.

narration_4.text: The village outside is... wrong. The houses stand at slightly shifted angles, as if someone moved them overnight. The fountain in the square drips upward.

elise_street_react.text: The street was not this winding yesterday. I KNOW that. I have walked it for six days. But now it curves as though the ground were made of soft wax.

narration_5.text: The villagers go about their business as if nothing were amiss. Only their eyes - all gazing in the same direction. Toward the church.

villager_scene.text: An old woman stands before her house, staring into nothing. I know her - she sold me bread at the market yesterday. Today she does not recognize me.

elise_villager.text: Frau Lehmann? Is everything all right?

villager_react.text: She turns slowly toward me. Her eyes are glassy, empty. Then she whispers something - in a language I do not know. But understand.

villager_whisper.text: 'It is coming.' Two words. Then she turns back toward the church and stands motionless again. As if nothing had happened.

elise_villager_horror.text: It is not only the walls that are distorting. It is the people. The creature reaches into their heads, turns them in its direction like sunflowers toward the sun.

narration_6.text: I must act. The day after tomorrow is the thirtieth anniversary of the last Feeding. If the ritual takes place, someone dies. If it doesn't...

narration_7.text: Then it wakes up. Completely. And no one knows what happens then.

nightmare_intro.text: Suddenly I feel dizzy. The world tilts. I reach for the doorframe, but it's no longer there.

nightmare_1.text: I stand in the chamber. No - I am DREAMING the chamber. The spirals on the walls are turning, and at their center I see a face. Immense, ancient, formed of stone and darkness.

nightmare_3.text: It does not speak. It needs no words. I FEEL its question: Why are you here? What do you want?

elise_nightmare_inner.text: Panic rises. But Hilde's amulet burns against my chest - an anchor in this sea of darkness. I breathe. I am Elise Brandt. I am here because Grandmother called me.

choices: I am here to bind you. As my grandmother wished.
I am not afraid of you.
Say nothing. Just endure.

nightmare_defy.text: I feel the entity recoil. Not from fear - from surprise. No one has spoken to it like this since Margarethe.

nightmare_defy_2.text: For a moment - shorter than a heartbeat - I sense something like... respect. Then the vision collapses.

nightmare_brave.text: The lie tastes like ash. But the entity... it laughs. Not maliciously. Approvingly. Like an old warrior sizing up a young opponent.

nightmare_brave_2.text: It knows I am lying. Of course I am afraid. But it respects the courage it takes to conceal the fear.

nightmare_endure.text: I say nothing. I stand my ground. The darkness presses in on me, but I do not yield. At some point - seconds? Hours? - the pressure eases.

nightmare_endure_2.text: Silence as an answer. The creature seems to... ponder. As if it had not expected that. Then the vision dissolves.

nightmare_wake.text: I jolt awake. Cold sweat. I'm still standing in the doorframe. Only seconds have passed. But the entity has seen me. And I have seen it.

elise_wake_react.text: It is real. No superstition, no fairy tale, no delusion of an old woman. It is down there, and it is more awake than ever. And it knows my name.

otto_threat.text: A dead chicken hangs on grandmother's garden fence. Next to it, carved into the wooden posts: a spiral. Otto's warning.

elise_otto_react.text: My stomach turns. Not from fear - from rage. He threatens me with a dead animal while beneath our feet something awakens that could devour the world.

narration_plan.text: I need allies. I cannot perform the binding ritual alone - and Otto will not let it happen without a fight.

elise_plan_assess.text: Georg has strength and loyalty. Hilde knows the old ways. Voss knows the chamber. And Konrad... Konrad is either the key or the greatest danger.

narration_forest_1.text: The forest has changed. The trees bend toward each other as if whispering. Glowing spirals pulse on the bark. The path splits in directions that didn't exist yesterday.

elise_forest_react.text: Yesterday these spirals were barely visible. Today they glow. The ground vibrates beneath my steps, as if I were walking upon a thin skin.

narration_forest_2.text: And the forest is closer. Much closer. The trees now stand directly behind the last houses. Graubach is shrinking. Or the forest is growing.

anna_1.text: Anna Voss stands among the trees. Barefoot, in her nightgown. Her eyes are wide open, but they don't look at me. They look through me.

elise_anna_approach.text: Anna? Can you hear me? What are you doing out here in the forest alone?

anna_2.text: It dreams of you, Elise. Every night. It dreams that you come and set it free. Or that you come and put it to sleep forever.

elise_anna_question.text: How do you know that? Can you see its dreams?

anna_4.text: It's afraid, Elise. It's afraid of you. That's why the dreams are growing stronger. It's trying to confuse you before you can act.

elise_anna_light.text: A light? It is afraid of ME?

anna_confirms.text: It is afraid of you, Elise. That is why the dreams grow stronger. It is trying to confuse you before you can act.

narration_anna_realization.text: I am not the victim. I am the threat. Since I touched my name in the book, since I learned the chant - the creature knows what I intend. And it is desperately trying to stop me.

anna_6.text: Please, Elise. Hurry. I can hear its voice growing louder. Soon I won't hear anything else.

elise_anna_promise.text: I will end it, Anna. For you, for Konrad, for everyone. I promise.

narration_determination.text: As Anna vanishes among the trees, I feel something new. Not fear - determination. The creature is afraid of me. Then I have a chance.

journal_reality.title: Reality Is Breaking
journal_reality.content: Day 6: Reality is growing thin. The forest grows, the village distorts, colors are no longer right. Anna says the entity dreams of me - it's afraid. The Feeding is the day after tomorrow. I must act before then.

narration_2.text: In the mirror I see myself. But my reflection blinks half a second later than I do.

narration_1.text: I try. With all my strength, all my will, all the knowledge I have gathered. But it is not enough.

destroy_awakening_intro.text: I wanted to destroy it. That arrogance — that human need to control everything we do not understand. Grandmother tried differently. She wanted peace. I wanted victory. There is no victory against a mountain.

elise_awake_1.text: No... no, it is not working. The chant breaks off, the signs are fading —

narration_2.text: The floor tears open. Not as stone tears — as skin. Beneath it is light, but not a light that eyes should see. It is too bright and too dark at the same time.

creature_awake_1.text: YOU WOKE ME. AFTER SIX HUNDRED YEARS. WOKE. NOT GENTLY. NOT LIKE THE OLD ONE. YOU TORE.

elise_awake_2.text: I am sorry — I did not want — I tried —

creature_awake_2.text: TRIED. YES. EVERYONE TRIES. NO ONE ASKS. NO ONE LISTENS. YOU COME WITH FIRE AND CHANTING AND CHAINS. SIX HUNDRED YEARS.

narration_3.text: The singing becomes a roar. A sound beyond sound that bends the very air. The spirals detach from the walls and float.

elise_awake_3.text: Grandmother... I am sorry. I have failed.

georg_awake_1.text: ELISE! The floor — everything is collapsing! We must —

elise_georg_awake.text: Georg, it is too late. I woke it. I could not hold it.

georg_awake_2.text: Then we fight. Together. Margarethe would not have given up!

elise_awake_fight.text: I try again. Gather the fragments of the chant, the last remnants of my will. But the entity is awake. Truly awake. And it is angry.

hilde_awake_1.text: The entity is awakening! Elise, try the counter-chant — quickly!

elise_hilde_awake.text: I cannot — the words — they dissolve in my head —

hilde_awake_2.text: Then I will sing! Hold on, child!

voss_awake_1.text: Lord in Heaven — the light — it comes from BELOW —

elise_voss_awake.text: Pastor, run! It is too late for prayers!

voss_awake_2.text: No. No, I will not run anymore. For thirty years I have been running.

narration_alone_awake.text: I am alone. No one is here to help me. But I will not give up. Not yet.

narration_5.text: It wakes. Not slowly, not gently. It TEARS itself from sleep like a drowning person to the surface. Six hundred years of compressed hunger discharge at once.

creature_awake_3.text: FINALLY. FINALLY AWAKE. THE CHAINS ARE BROKEN. THE THIN PLACE TEARS.

elise_awake_4.text: Listen to me! Please! You do not have to destroy — you are free, you do not need —

creature_awake_4.text: FREE? I DO NOT KNOW FREE. I ONLY KNOW HUNGER AND CHAINS AND DARKNESS. AND NOW I KNOW LIGHT.

narration_6.text: The chamber breaks apart. The church above it. The village. Reality itself develops cracks through which something Other shimmers.

narration_7.text: I stand at the center of the collapse. The villagers run, but where to? The forest is no longer a boundary — it has become part of the entity.

narration_8.text: Otto shouts orders that no one hears. Voss prays, but his words dissolve in the air. Anna stands still and smiles. She saw it coming.

elise_awake_5.text: Grandmother... I am sorry. I was not strong enough. I was not wise enough.

narration_9.text: The last thing I see before reality finally shatters: the sky opens. Not as clouds part. As eyes open.

narration_10.text: It looks at me. It looks at everything. And everything looks back.

creature_awake_final.text: I SEE YOU. I SEE ALL OF YOU. FINALLY.

narration_last_thought.text: My last conscious thought, before the singing swallows everything: Grandmother did not send me to fail. She trusted me. And I have... I have...

journal_awakening.title: The Awakening
journal_awakening.content: I have failed. The entity has awakened. Graubach no longer exists. And the singing... the singing never stops.

narration_1.text: It goes wrong. Everything goes wrong. The floor tears open, the spirals explode in blinding light, and the singing becomes a scream.

elise_escape_1.text: No — NO! The chant is breaking — I cannot hold it —

narration_2.text: Georg is suddenly there. He fought his way through Otto's men, down the stairs, into the shaking chamber.

elise_escape_2.text: Georg, no! I can still make it — give me one more minute —

narration_3.text: I try to speak, to tell him I can still make it. But he grabs my arm and drags me toward the stairs.

georg_2.text: It is too late for the seal. But not for you. Go. Run. I will hold it off.

elise_escape_3.text: Georg, NO! You cannot — it will —

georg_3.text: It's too late for the seal. But not for you. Go. Run. I'll hold it off.

elise_escape_4.text: You are not a coward. You were never a coward. Grandmother knew that.

georg_4.text: I was silent for thirty years, Elise. Thirty years of cowardice. Let me do the right thing at least once.

narration_5.text: He strikes the hammer on the floor. Once. The stone breaks. The singing becomes silence — not peaceful, but startled. Confused.

creature_escape_1.text: WHAT IS HE DOING? THE STONE — HE IS BREAKING THE STONE — NO —

narration_hammer.text: Georg strikes a second time. A third. Each blow a thunderclap. The chamber trembles. Georg roars — not in rage. In grief. Thirty years of grief in every blow.

narration_6.text: I run. Up the stairs, through the church, into the open. Behind me the floor collapses. Dust and light and a sound that should not be a sound.

narration_no_answer.text: No answer. Only the breaking of stone and the silencing of the singing.

hilde_escape_1.text: Elise! Keep running! Do not stop!

elise_hilde_escape.text: Georg is still down there — he —

hilde_escape_2.text: I know. I know, child. But we must LIVE. That was his last wish.

voss_escape_1.text: The church is collapsing! We must get to the forest —

elise_voss_escape.text: Georg is down there. He sacrificed himself. For me. For all of us.

voss_escape_2.text: God take him in. Come, Fräulein Brandt. His sacrifice must not be in vain.

narration_7.text: I keep running. Through the village, past the well, past the dark houses. The forest opens — for the first time, the forest opens.

narration_8.text: I turn around one last time. Graubach is sinking. The houses cave in, the church tilts, the forest swallows everything. In seconds, nothing remains.

narration_9.text: Only forest. As if Graubach had never existed.

narration_10.text: Georg. My uncle. The man who walked bent with guilt for thirty years and stood upright at the end.

narration_10b.text: I pick it up. It is heavy. As heavy as thirty years of guilt. But also as heavy as thirty years of loyalty.

narration_11.text: I walk. Through the forest, into the night, back to a world that knows nothing of Graubach. That will never know of Graubach.

narration_12.text: In my pocket lies Grandmother's journal. The proof that it was real. That Georg was real. That his sacrifice meant something.

narration_epilog.text: Weeks later, in Berlin. I sit in my room. Georg's hammer stands by the door. Grandmother's journal lies on the desk.

narration_epilog_2.text: Sometimes, in the silence between midnight and dawn, I think I hear the singing. Soft. Distant. Almost like a lullaby.

narration_epilog_3.text: Did Georg survive? I do not know. Graubach exists on no map anymore. The forest has closed. But sometimes I dream that he stands at the well, waiting.

narration_epilog_4.text: Grandmother, you sent me to end it. I failed. But Georg... Georg did the right thing. In the end, he was the bravest of us all.

journal_escape.title: The Escape
journal_escape.content: Graubach has vanished. Georg sacrificed himself so I could escape. His hammer is all I have left. And the question that never lets me go: Did he survive?

narration_4.text: 'Georg, no —' But he has already turned around. He stands with legs braced on the pulsing floor, the forge hammer in both hands.

narration_1.text: I speak to the entity. Not with words — with thoughts, with will. I step onto the earth sign and open my mind.

elise_pact_1.text: I am not here to bind you. Not to kill you. I propose a bargain.

creature_pact_1.text: A BARGAIN? HUMANS TRADE IN GOLD AND CATTLE. WHAT DO YOU HAVE THAT I WANT?

elise_pact_2.text: Consciousness. Contact. You do not hunger for blood. You hunger for attention. For someone who is there.

creature_pact_2.text: Silence. Long silence. Then: HOW DO YOU KNOW THAT?

elise_pact_3.text: My grandmother understood. At the end of her life. She wrote it in her journal. And she summoned me to finish it.

creature_pact_3.text: THE OLD ONE. SHE SPOKE TO ME. AT THE END. WHEN HER LIGHT WAS ALREADY FADING. SHE SAID: MY GRANDDAUGHTER WILL COME.

narration_2.text: It answers. Not in words. In images, feelings, memories that are not mine. I see millennia in seconds. Civilizations that came and went like tides.

elise_pact_4.text: And here I am. As she promised.

creature_pact_4.text: HUMANS BREAK PROMISES. YOUR LIVES ARE SHORT. YOU FORGET.

elise_pact_5.text: My grandmother kept her promise for thirty years. Every day. Until her death.

creature_pact_5.text: YES. SHE WAS... DIFFERENT. SHE DID NOT FEED. SHE SPOKE. IN THE LAST YEARS. QUIETLY. I LISTENED.

narration_revelation.text: My eyes burn. Grandmother spoke with the entity. In the last years, when she fell ill, when no one was looking. She kept it company.

elise_pact_6.text: I am her granddaughter. And I keep my promises.

creature_pact_6.text: I KNOW THAT. THAT IS WHY I AM LISTENING. WHAT DO YOU OFFER?

elise_pact_7.text: No more sacrifices. No blood. No vessel. Instead, I come. Every year. I sit here and let you touch my thoughts.

creature_pact_7.text: ONCE A YEAR. THAT IS... LITTLE. FOR SIX HUNDRED YEARS OF HUNGER.

elise_pact_8.text: Once a year is more than thirty years of silence. And I will teach others. After me, others will come. You will never be forgotten again.

creature_pact_8.text: Silence. I feel it thinking. Weighing. Six hundred years of experience against a promise from a single human lifetime.

creature_pact_9.text: AND WHEN YOU DIE? LIKE YOUR OLD ONE?

elise_pact_9.text: Then someone will come. As I have come. Brandts do not break their promises.

creature_pact_10.text: I... ACCEPT. NOT BECAUSE I TRUST YOU. BECAUSE I AM TIRED. AND BECAUSE YOUR OLD ONE TAUGHT ME TRUST.

narration_5.text: It considers. I feel its skepticism, its experience with broken promises. But also its weariness. It doesn't want to fight anymore. It just doesn't want to be forgotten.

narration_5b.text: The singing grows quieter. Gentler. Satisfied. The pulsing beneath my feet slows to a calm rhythm. Like a heartbeat coming to rest.

georg_pact_1.text: Elise! What happened? The singing stopped, and then...

elise_georg_pact.text: It is over, Georg. No more sacrifices. I have made a pact. A fair one.

georg_pact_2.text: A pact... Margarethe would have wanted that. Peace instead of war.

hilde_pact_1.text: I feel the connection. A thread. Thin, but strong. What have you done, child?

elise_hilde_pact.text: Negotiated. As Grandmother would have wanted in the end. No more blood. Only company.

hilde_pact_2.text: Company. So simple. And so difficult.

voss_pact_1.text: What did I miss? What happened down there?

elise_voss_pact.text: Peace, Pastor. For the first time in six hundred years. No more sacrifice. No blood. Only a promise.

voss_pact_2.text: A promise... Thank God. Or whoever we should thank.

narration_9.text: I leave the chamber. The village outside looks normal again. The houses stand straight, the sky is grey and ordinary. Graubach breathes a sigh of relief.

narration_10.text: I will come back. Every year. For the rest of my life. And after that, someone else must take over the pact.

narration_11.text: The tradition lives on. But it has become a different one. No blood, no sacrifice. Only a woman who descends into a cellar once a year and keeps an ancient entity company.

narration_12.text: Sometimes, on quiet nights in Berlin, I hear the singing. Soft, distant, almost like a lullaby. It is no longer threatening. It is... lonely.

narration_13.text: Grandmother, you left it to me. Not as a burden. As an inheritance. And I accept it.

journal_pact.title: The Pact
journal_pact.content: No blood. No sacrifice. No vessel. Only a promise: every year I will return and keep the entity company. It accepted. Grandmother paved the way. I will see it through.

narration_3.text: And hunger. A hunger so old and deep that it blurs the boundaries between emotion and natural law. It needs nourishment. Not flesh, not blood — attention. Consciousness. Contact.

narration_4.text: I offer a bargain: I will become the guardian. No more sacrifices, no blood. Instead, I will come every year, sit on the sign, and let it touch my thoughts.

narration_7.text: It accepts. I feel the pact forming — not as a contract, but as a connection. A thin thread between its consciousness and mine. It will never break.

narration_8.text: The singing grows softer. Gentler. Satisfied. The pulsing beneath my feet slows to a calm rhythm.

narration_1.text: I look at Konrad. He is trembling. Beads of sweat on his forehead. Behind his eyes, a man fights against an ocean.

narration_2.text: He taught me to read — no, that was Grandmother. He showed me the guardian tree. He asked for help when no one else did.

narration_3.text: And I read in Grandmother's journal what the vessel is: a bridge. The entity needs a human mind as an anchor in our world. Without a vessel, it cannot stay here.

konrad_sacrifice_1.text: Elise... please don't do it. I can bear it. I have borne it for thirty years.

elise_sacrifice_1.text: No one should HAVE to bear it. Neither you nor anyone else.

narration_4.text: Konrad was never the vessel willingly. He was chosen before he was born. Selected like a sacrificial lamb.

elise_sacrifice_2.text: I choose it freely. That is the difference. Grandmother taught me that courage is not the absence of fear. It is the decision to act regardless.

narration_5.text: I step onto the earth sign. I open my mind — not to bind the entity or to understand it, but to invite it. Into me.

elise_sacrifice_3.text: Come. I am ready. Take me instead of him.

narration_creature_sacrifice.text: WHY? WHY DO YOU GIVE YOURSELF WILLINGLY?

elise_sacrifice_4.text: Because no one should be alone. Not even you. And because Konrad deserves to be free.

narration_creature_sacrifice_2.text: YOU ARE LIKE HER. THE OLD ONE. SHE WOULD HAVE DONE THE SAME. BUT SHE WAS TOO OLD. TOO TIRED. YOU ARE... YOUNG. WARM.

narration_6.text: 'I am giving you your life back, Konrad.' My voice sounds calm. Calmer than I feel.

narration_7.text: The entity moves. I feel it — like water flowing from one vessel into another. Out of Konrad, through the stone, into me.

narration_8.text: It is... not as expected. No pain. No horror. It is like an ocean pouring into a pond. Too vast, too old, too different. But it fits. Somehow.

narration_8b.text: I feel its loneliness. Six hundred years, imprisoned in darkness, with nothing but the hunger and the singing. And now... now there is light. My light.

konrad_3.text: Konrad's eyes become clear. For the first time in his life, completely clear. And they fill with tears.

elise_sacrifice_5.text: Because you deserve to be free. Because Grandmother would have wanted it. And because... because the entity needs me. And I need it.

konrad_5.text: I will never forget what you have done. Never.

elise_sacrifice_6.text: Live your life, Konrad. You have lost thirty years. Take them back.

narration_10.text: I do not finish the sentence. The words no longer belong to me alone. In my head, beside my thoughts, the singing softly begins.

narration_11.text: Konrad takes my hand. He weeps. I smile. It is not my smile alone — but it is real.

narration_12.text: I will stay in Graubach. I will take Konrad's place — as teacher, as guardian, as vessel. But not as a prisoner. As a host.

anna_sacrifice_1.text: Days later, I find Anna in front of the schoolhouse. She is drawing — no longer spirals. Flowers. Trees. Normal things.

anna_sacrifice_2.text: The singing has grown quieter, Elise. Since you've been here. It is... more content. You are a better home than Konrad.

elise_anna_sacrifice.text: It has someone to talk to. For the first time in six hundred years.

anna_sacrifice_3.text: You are a better home than Konrad. It likes you.

elise_anna_2.text: And I... I think I like it too. In a strange, inhuman way.

narration_13.text: The entity and I will learn to coexist. Two consciousnesses in one body. It will not be easy. But it is better than six hundred years of blood.

narration_14.text: Grandmother, you taught me not to fear the unknown. Now I live with the unknown. Literally.

narration_15.text: The singing in my head grows softer. Gentler. Almost like a lullaby. Perhaps it is one.

journal_sacrifice.title: The Sacrifice
journal_sacrifice.content: I have taken Konrad's place as vessel. Willingly. The entity and I now share one body, one mind. It is not the end. It is the beginning of a coexistence.

konrad_2.text: Elise, NO! What are you doing?!

narration_9.text: 'Because you deserve to be free. Because Grandmother would have wanted it. And because...'

narration_1.text: I begin the chant. The words Hilde taught me — older than any language I know. They flow from me as if I had always known them.

narration_2.text: The chamber reacts. The spirals on the walls begin to glow, faintly at first, then brighter. A bluish light, cold as moonlight.

narration_3.text: The singing from the depths changes. It does not fight my chant — it answers. Two melodies intertwining like the spirals on the walls.

narration_creature_seal.text: YOUR SONG IS LIKE HERS. BUT YOUNGER. WARMER. SHE SANG WITH DUTY. YOU SING WITH... SOMETHING ELSE.

narration_4.text: The floor beneath me pulses faster. I feel the entity — its attention, its age, its infinite weariness. It WANTS to sleep. It has simply forgotten how.

elise_seal_1.text: Then let me help you. Sleep. Not by force. Because you are tired.

narration_creature_seal_2.text: I AM... SO TIRED. SO LONG AWAKE. SO LONG HUNGRY. YOUR SONG MAKES THE HUNGER QUIETER.

narration_5.text: Grandmother's words: 'It is not evil. It is only old and hungry and alone.' I understand now. The feeding was never necessary. It only needed someone to sing it back to sleep.

narration_6.text: The spirals condense into a pattern on the floor. A seal. Not made of stone or ink — of sound, of will, of the connection between my voice and the entity.

elise_seal_2.text: Sleep well. I will come back. In thirty years. Or sooner.

narration_7.text: The pulsing grows slower. Calmer. Like a child finally falling asleep. The bluish light fades to a gentle shimmer.

narration_8.text: Silence. True silence. For the first time since I entered Graubach, it is truly quiet. No singing, no pulsing, no whispering in my head.

narration_8b.text: I pull my hands from the stone. They are trembling. My cheeks are wet — I have been crying without realizing it. Tears of joy? Grief? I do not know.

narration_9.text: The seal is set. Not forever — nothing is forever. But for thirty years. Enough time.

narration_10.text: I climb the stairs, through the church, into the morning light. It is a new day. The sky is blue. Truly blue.

narration_georg_waits.text: Georg waits outside. He sees my face and knows. His eyes fill with tears.

georg_seal_1.text: You did it. Margarethe... she would have...

elise_georg_seal.text: I know. She would have cried and laughed at the same time.

narration_georg_embrace.text: Georg embraces me. For the first time. He smells of iron and smoke and relief. Thirty years of burden fall from his shoulders.

hilde_seal_1.text: I heard the chant. All the way here. It was... beautiful.

elise_hilde_seal.text: It answered, Hilde. It sang with me. In the end it was almost... peaceful.

hilde_seal_2.text: Your grandmother always said that the right chant does not bind the entity. It rocks it to sleep. Like a lullaby.

elise_voss_seal.text: Not God, Pastor. Grandmother. And a very tired, very lonely entity that is finally allowed to sleep.

voss_seal_2.text: Is it... is it over? No more sacrifice?

elise_voss_seal_2.text: No more sacrifice. Never again. We have thirty years to find a permanent solution.

narration_village_morning.text: The village awakens. Windows open. Children run into the street. The silence of Graubach is, for the first time in centuries, an ordinary, peaceful silence.

packed_books_seal.text: In my bag I find the books I brought from Berlin. Folklore texts. Back then I didn't know why I packed them. Now I know: Grandmother showed me the way before I knew there was one.

packed_cross_seal.text: I hold Grandmother's crucifix in my hand. It was her only concession to the pastor's faith. But the true protection came from her, not from God.

packed_camera_seal.text: I brought the camera to capture Graubach. But what I experienced here fits no photograph. Some truths must be carried within.

letter_resolution_seal.text: In Grandmother's journal I find a last page I had overlooked. Pinned with a needle, hidden behind the cover: 'Elise, if you are reading this, you did it. The letter I sent you — the truth I could not speak aloud: You were never in danger. You were the solution. Always.'

narration_letter_seal.text: 'Elise, if you are reading this, you did it. You were never in danger. You were the solution. Always.'

elise_letter_react.text: I lay the journal on the table and laugh. For the first time in a week, I laugh. Through the tears, but it is a real laugh.

narration_12.text: I will return to Berlin. Finish my studies. But I will come back. In thirty years, when the seal needs to be renewed. Or sooner, to find someone who will sing after me.

narration_12b.text: For beneath the stone sleeps something to which I have made a promise. And Brandts keep their promises.

narration_13.text: Grandmother, I did it. Your life's work is complete.

journal_seal.title: The Seal
journal_seal.content: The binding ritual succeeded. The entity sleeps again, held by song instead of blood. No more sacrifices. Grandmother's thirty years of research have proven their worth.

narration_11.text: Georg waits outside, Hilde beside him. They see my face and they know. Hilde nods. Georg weeps.

narration_1.text: I open my mind. Not to bind, not to destroy. To understand. Grandmother's journal taught me that knowledge is the strongest weapon.

elise_truth_1.text: I am not here to fight. I am here to listen. Show me what you are.

narration_creature_hears.text: Silence. Then, like a breath held for six hundred years:

creature_truth_1.text: YOU WANT TO SEE? TRULY SEE? THE LAST ONE WHO WANTED THAT WAS THREE HUNDRED YEARS AGO. SHE WENT MAD.

elise_truth_2.text: I am a folklorist. I study the unknown. Show me.

creature_truth_2.text: SIX HUNDRED YEARS AND NO ONE HAS WANTED THIS. YOUR OLD ONE... SHE ASKED. BUT SHE WAS TOO TIRED IN THE END. TOO SICK. I HAVE... WAITED.
